NET, the National Educational Television and
Radio Center, is headquarters and chief national
spokesman for the fifty affiliated educational tele¬
vision stations, and the main stimulus and ex¬
change medium for noninstructional programs.
NET helps affiliates keep abreast of developments
in ETV. Visits by station-relations staff, meetings
of all station managers and program managers,
and a monthly newsletter help stations compare
notes on fund-raising, promotion, and public re¬
lations. One objective: to increase the audience
for programs distributed by NET. Another: feed¬
back to NET of audience reaction to programs
that have been televised nationally.
The core of NET’s operations is the program
service. The Center provides each station eight
hours a week of programs: six hours of new mate¬
rial and two drawn from NET’s growing backlog
of programs — about 1,900 hours at last count.
Most programs come from the stations themselves.
A program idea from a station is accepted by the
Center for national exchange on the basis of its
quality and interest to other affiliates. The Center
pays most of the costs.
Other program ideas originate at the Center and
are farmed out to one of the stations for produc¬
tion. Still other sources of programs: the British
Broadcasting Corporation, the French Television
Network, and occasional outstanding commercial-
television shows of educational value. Conversely,
some commercial television stations have pur¬
chased NET programs, especially for showing in
cities without ETV channels.
NET claims the title of “fourth network.” The
evidence: quality, educational content, flexibility, ;
and visibility of its program service. “It’s not '
blind reverence for the educational label that
leads people to watch NET programs,” says an
official. ‘ ‘ We ’re competing for their attention with |
quality. We consider dullness a criminal offense.
We try to make our programs interesting without
sugar-coating and without watering down the val¬
idity of the educational material.”
Visibility: ETV stations make such programming
available not just occasionally, or on a Sunday
afternoon, but every evening, in the prime view¬
ing hours between dinner and bedtime.
Flexibility: If a program is of unusual interest,
many ETV stations telecast it twice the same day
or several times a week.
Content: NET’s programming covers six basic
areas: public affairs, children’s programs, sci-|
ence, the social sciences, humanities, and the arts.
